Elizabeth McConartv. Massachusetts Board of Educational Television: "There are
nine members of the METV Board and I am one of the four citizen members. We do
public relations work, and, with some 250-300 high school students, we produce
scripts for educational programs. Our work culminates with a day in May, when the
students take over a commercial station and run it for 12 hours. Many of our students
go on in the field after high school graduation and at that time may have had up to
six years of work at the station. In about a year, we hope to move into TV."
Kendall Crane. WDUQ-FM. Pittsburgh. Pa: "Our station, WDUQ-FM, was set up
in 1949 and in a year we had about 2300 listeners. We are supported by the UniverÂ¬
sity and have 40 students working with us - four paid staff members, two engineers
and myself. Wow we have well over 20,000 listeners. We are on the air 364 days
a year with one day out for the annual picnic, and go from 10:00 A. 11. to 1:45 daily,
covering 17 different subjects. Our programs are for in-school listening, and we
are the official station for parochial schools in Pittsburgh. We make use of as
much NAEB material as we can and cover basketball and high school football games as
well as the home games of the University."
Rosalind Roulston. United Community Services. Boston: "My work is with the
United Community Services which some of you know as Community Chest and Red Feather.
In Boston, however, we are joined into one group which combines just short of 300
health and social welfare services. In 1952, the organization became interested
in ETV as a means to extend our services in the area. Last December we expanded
our TV activities and now go all over the Commonwealth and set up workshops known
as community technical workshops. By way of personal identification I had the
pleasure of being a student at the first WAEB Production Workshop at Urbana in 1953."
